ifconfig [-a] or ip a are the commands that will generally give you basic networking information on a nix machine.
Across the various nix variants, you can set and view persistent networking configurations via different mechanisms.
Note: You can configure Solaris 11 networking information via: ipadm and dladm. ipadm configures network layer settings. dladm configures data-link layer settings.

Network Interface Cards (NICs) are typically named in a couple of manners.
This traditional kernel naming scheme for NICs is unpredictable and is the default if nothing specific is set.
Example: eth0
Example: eno1
Example: ens1, enp2s0 (PCI 2, Slot 0)
Example: enx78e7d1ea46da
Viewing the ARP table can provide good passive information about active clients on the same network.
The routing table for devices can tell you the default gateway and any static routes for the device.
Understanding active network connections can give you a lot of information about listening services on the system as well as any current connections to or from a remote system.
Understanding any manually set DNS servers can be useful in enumerating local DNS servers that are resolving local domain names.
Note: For machines using NetworkManager, you can use the following command to find DNS servers in use: nmcli c show nic name | grep dns
